[[File:Baron52crashsite.jpg|thumb|250px|Aerial reconnaissance photo of the Baron 52 crash site in Salavan Province, Laos, 1973. The fuselage lays upside down and both wings were severed.]] '''Baron 52''' was the call sign of a United States Air Force [[EC-47]] carrying eight crew members that was shot down over [[Laos]] during the predawn hours of 5 February 1973, a week after the [[Paris Peace Accords]] officially ended the US's involvement in the [[Vietnam War]].<ref name="Oregon">{{cite news|last1=Francis|first1=Mike|title=Still seeking answers about Joseph Matejov and many others missing in war|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/pacific-northwest-news/index.ssf/2014/01/still_seeking_answers_about_jo.html|accessdate=9 February 2016|work=The Oregonian|date=12 January 2014}}</ref> The remains of four crewmen were recovered from the crash site, but those of the remaining four have never been found. Although the US government considers them to have been [[killed in action]] and as late as 1996 listed them as "accounted for", family members and POW/MIA advocates believe the four survived the crash and were taken captive and possibly sent to the USSR.<ref name="SandS">{{cite news|last1=Burke|first1=Matthew M.|title=Lynn O'Shea, advocate for POW/MIA families, dies at 65|url=http://www.stripes.com/news/lynn-o-shea-advocate-for-pow-mia-families-dies-at-65-1.383166|accessdate=9 February 2016|work=Stars and Stripes|date=10 December 2015}}</ref><ref name="Yurick">{{cite book|last1=Yurick|first1=Terry|title=AP Alley|date=2014|publisher=Lulu Enterprises Inc|isbn=1483407101|page=xi|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xVynAgAAQBAJ&pg=PR11&lpg=PR11&dq=unsolved+mysteries+baron+52&source=bl&ots=F_weU1paL-&sig=2oeSSR17P7ylWtxoAG9_X448gqM&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjPr960r-_KAhUNzGMKHT-fB6sQ6AEITDAL#v=onepage&q=unsolved%20mysteries%20baron%2052&f=false|accessdate=11 February 2016}}</ref> The intelligence gatherers and their equipment would have been highly valued by the Soviets who maintained a presence both in Laos and North Vietnam.<ref name="Sauter" /> The incident has been featured on several nationwide news programs and a [[List of Unsolved Mysteries episodes#Season 4 (1991-92)|1991 episode]] of the US television series ''[[Unsolved Mysteries]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Baron 52|url=http://unsolved.com/archives/baron-52|website=Unsolved Mysteries|accessdate=10 February 2016}}</ref><ref name=Yurick /> More recent research by the [[National Alliance of Families for the Return of America’s Servicemen]] presented to Congress has prompted a status review of the incident scheduled to take place in 2016.<ref name=SandS />
==The mission== Although the Paris Peace Accords had officially ended the United States' direct role in the Vietnam War, only a week after its signing the US Air Force sent an EC-47Q electronic warfare collection aircraft on a night-time radio-direction-finding mission to monitor the [[Ho Chi Minh trail]] and locate North Vietnamese tanks moving south. The plane, tail number 43-48636, belonged to the [[361st Tactical Electronic Warfare Squadron]] and began its mission from [[Ubon Royal Thai Air Force Base]]. The flight crew also were part of the 361st while the collection crew manning the rear of the plane were from Det 3, 6994th Security Squadron.<ref name="SecSquad">{{cite web|title=Baron 52|url=http://6994th.com/?page_id=123|website=6994th Security Squadron|accessdate=9 February 2016}}</ref> Over Laos, the plane began taking anti-aircraft fire and went down in [[Salavan Province]], Laos about 50 miles east of the city of [[Salavan (city)|Salavan]] and 20 miles from the border with South Vietnam at a site in the jungle within eight miles of three major roads leading into North Vietnamese-held territory.
==Crew== 361st Tactical Electronic Warfare Squadron:<ref name=AFMil>{{cite news|last1=White |first1=Dillon |title=70th ISR Wing Airmen, Vietnam Veterans remember fallen heroes |url=http://www.25af.af.mil/news/story_print.asp?id=123405005 |accessdate=10 February 2016 |work=Air Force Print News |agency=70th ISR Wing Public Affairs office |publisher=United States Air Force |date=26 March 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160216045841/http://www.25af.af.mil/news/story_print.asp?id=123405005 |archivedate=16 February 2016 |df= }}</ref>
*Capt. George R. Spitz – Pilot *2nd Lt Severo J. Primm III – Co-Pilot *Capt. Arthur R. Bollinger – Navigator *1st Lt Robert E. Bernhardt – 3rd Pilot
6994th Security Squadron:<ref name=AFMil />
*SSgt Todd M. Melton – Radio Operator *Sgt Joseph A. Matejov – Radio Operator *Sgt Peter R. Cressman – Radio Operator *Sgt Dale Brandenburg – Systems Repair Technician
==Recovery efforts== The location of the wreckage was first discovered by US Air Force search and rescue on 7 February 1973. The plane was determined to have crashed inverted, coming to rest upside down in the jungle; both wings had been sheered off. A team consisting of three [[United States Air Force Pararescue|pararescuemen]] and an intelligence expert were on the ground for approximately an hour and found three bodies in the charred wreckage, those of Spitz, Prim and Bollinger in the cockpit, still strapped in their seats. Outside of the wreckage, they found Lt. Bernhardt's body. In the rear of the plane they observed the jump door had been removed (it was never located), the crew's safety belts were unbuckled, and all of the top secret sensitive equipment was missing as were the rear crew's parachutes.<ref name="Oregon" /><ref name="TFOorg">{{cite web|title=MATEJOV, JOSEPH ANDREW "JOE"|url=http://taskforceomegainc.org/m194.html|website=TaskForceOmegaInc.org|publisher=Task Force Omega, Inc. 501 (c) (3)|accessdate=11 February 2016}}</ref>
On 9 February 1973, Bernhardt's remains were recovered and positively identified four days later. On 22 February, the other seven men were declared killed in action despite no confirmation of the fates of the four members of the collection crew.<ref name="TFOorg" />
==Controversy== The families of the missing crew members believe there is evidence they bailed out and were taken captive by the [[North Vietnamese Army]] (NVA). They point to information in official reports, such as the fact that their safety belts were unbuckled and their remains were not at the crash site, to support their beliefs that the rear crew had time to bail out.<ref name="Oregon" /> In addition, at approximately 8:00 AM on 5 February, US Intelligence listening post at [[Phu Bai Combat Base]] in South Vietnam intercepted NVA communications from the area indicating they were transporting four captured Airmen. Such communications continued to be intercepted for the next three months. Also on record is a [[Pathet Lao]] radio intercept regarding four "air pirates" captured the day Baron 52 was shot down; no other US aircraft was downed that day. A Laotian operative secretly working for the US reported observing the transport of four prisoners along the road near the crash site.<ref name="Oregon" /> All of these records remained classified by the US government. This evidence was first presented to the American public by columnist [[Jack Anderson (columnist)|Jack Anderson]] on the US news program ''[[Good Morning America]]'' in 1978. During Anderson's report, he stated a "Pentagon spokesman now agrees there's a good chance these four men were survivors of the crash. Yet, the Pentagon deliberately gave the families misinformation".<ref name=House95>Subcommittee, United States. Congress. House. Committee On National Security. Military Personnel. [http://www.forgottenbooks.com/readbook_text/Department_of_Defenses_Comprehensive_Review_of_Indochina_Pow_1000867367/45 ''Department of Defense's Comprehensive Review of Indochina Pow''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160216101907/http://www.forgottenbooks.com/readbook_text/Department_of_Defenses_Comprehensive_Review_of_Indochina_Pow_1000867367/45 |date=February 16, 2016 }}. Reprint. London: Forgotten Books, 2013. 38-9. Print. Retrieved 10 February 2016.</ref>
In 1992, in front of the [[Senate Select Committee on POW/MIA Affairs]], a representative of the Defense Intelligence Agency testified that it was the government's position that these reports were unrelated to Baron 52; this testimony was repeated in 1994 before the [[United States House of Representatives|House]] Subcommittee on Asia and the Pacific of the Committee on Foreign Affairs.<ref name=House94>{{cite web|title=Full text of "POW/MIA, where do we go from here: hearing before the Subcommittee on Asia and the Pacific of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, House of Representatives, One Hundred Third Congress, second session, February 10, 1994|url=https://archive.org/stream/powmiawheredoweg00unit/powmiawheredoweg00unit_djvu.txt|website=archive.org|publisher=The Internet Archive|accessdate=11 February 2016}}</ref> In November of 1992, the Lao government allowed a team to survey the crash site where a [[dogtag]] with Sgt. Matejov's name on it was found, after nearly 20 years, laying in plain sight. Also recovered were 23 bone fragments and half of a tooth which were taken to the [[Joint POW/MIA Accounting Command|Central Identification Laboratory]] in Hawaii, where [[Ellis R. Kerley]] publicly stated that the bone fragments "can not be proven conclusively to be human." According to further testimony given before the House Subcommittee by [[Albert Santoli]], Kerley was replaced by "a U.S. Army Lt. Colonel, professionally a dentist, who has limited forensic experience",<ref name=House94 /> and the bone fragments were declared to be the remains of all seven of the remaining crew members. The families requested DNA analysis be done on the bone fragments and tooth, but their requests were denied by the government.<ref name="Oregon" />
On 27 March 1996, the bone fragments were interred at Arlington National Cemetery in a group burial. The families of all seven men attended although the families of the four rear crew members were there to "honor the sacrifice" of the flight crew and did not believe the bone fragments were those of either Melton, Matejov, Cressman or Brandenburg.<ref name="Oregon" /> Matejov's younger brother, John Matejov, has sought help from both Wyoming Senators and Congressmen in petitioning the Pentagon for further information as well as appealing directly to President Obama.<ref name="Oregon" /> Former Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense Roger Shields said the government "acted 'precipitously' to declare Matejov and the other three missing crew members to be dead".<ref name= Oregon /> In their book, ''The Men We Left Behind'', Mark Sauter and Jim Sanders wrote that "The names were scratched from the list (of MIAs) because they were an inconvenience that would have complicated Henry Kissinger's life".<ref name="Sauter">{{cite book|last1=Sauter|first1=Mark|last2=Sanders|first2=Jim|title=The men we left behind: Henry Kissinger, the politics of deceit and the tragic fate of POWs after the Vietnam War|date=1993|publisher=National Press Book|location=University of Wisconsin - Madison|edition=illustrated|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=k3fxAAAAMAAJ&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=they+were+an+inconvenience+that+would|accessdate=11 February 2016}}</ref> [[Henry Kissinger|Kissinger]] negotiated the Paris Peace Accords and was responsible for carrying out President Nixon's promise to bring all [[Prisoner of War|POWs]] home.<ref name="WashPost">{{cite news|last1=Lippman|first1=Thomas W.|title=MYSTERY OF THE LAST FLIGHT OF BARON 52 SOLVED|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1995/12/10/mystery-of-the-last-flight-of-baron-52-solved/dad9c028-daca-46bc-a25f-87fffe1e5051/|accessdate=11 February 2016|work=The Washington Post|date=10 December 1995}}</ref> They further alleged that "the men weren't dead, and the Pentagon knew it" and that it was covered up because the flight was illegal under the Paris agreement.<ref name=WashPost />
Congress is set to review the status of the four crewmen in 2016.<ref name=SandS /> The status of one of the four crewman was not changed to MIA 2016.<ref>[http://www.stripes.com/news/air-force-denies-mia-status-for-airman-in-vietnam-era-baron-52-case-1.438632 US Stars and Stripes 2016]</ref>
